dc:description:
TTN was originally evaluated for DCM by ClinGen DCM GCEP on September 29, 2020. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated on 3/19/2025. As a result, the classification did not change. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of t/he gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein.

Titin (TTN) was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) in 2002 (Gerull et al, 2002, PMID: 22335739). Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, case-control data and segregation data. Over 100 truncating TTN variants (TTNtv) have been reported in humans with DCM (Gerull et al, 2006, PMID: 16733766; Herman et al, 2012 PMID: 22335739; Norton et al, 2013, PMID: 23418287; Akinrinade et al, 2015, PMID: 26084686; Franaszczyk et al, 2017, PMID: 28045875; Akinrinade et al, 2019, PMID: 30858397; Cannatà et al, 2022, PMID: 35138330; Massier, 2025, PMID: 39844436). Strong case-control data has been reported in a study comparing the frequency of TTNtv in large populations of healthy volunteers and DCM patients (Roberts et al, 2015, PMID: 25589632; Haggerty et al, 2019, PMID: 31216868). In addition, this gene-disease association is supported by experimental data including animal models (zebrafish – Xu et al, 2002, PMID: 11788825; mouse – Gramlich et al, 2009, PMID: 19406126 and rat – Schafer et al, 2017, PMID: 27869827); human induced pluripotent stem cell studies (Hinson et al, 2015, PMID: 26315439) and phenotype rescue experiments in animal models and human induced pluripotent stem cells from DCM patients (Gramlich et al, 2015, PMID: 25759365). Ghahremani et al (2024, PMID: 38235591) showed that in human iPSC models TTN CRISPR activation rescued TTN truncating variants-related functional deficits (normalized sarcomere content and contractile function). Additional evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence and/or experimental evidence has been reached. TTN has also been curated by the Congenital Myopathies gene curation expert group for TTN-related myopathy (Definitive, 01/11/2022), the Congenital Myopathies gene curation expert group for tibial muscular dystrophy (Moderate, 03/14/2022), the Congenital Myopathies gene curation expert group for myopathy, myofibrillar, 9, with early respiratory failure (Moderate, 03/14/2022), the Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease gene curation expert group for HCM (Limited, 07/27/2023), and the Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy gene curation expert group for ARVC (Limited, 08/06/2019).  In summary, truncating variants TTN are definitively associated with autosomal dominant DCM. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on September 29, 2020 (SOP Version 7). This written summary was updated on 3/19/2025 and approved by the DCM GCEP on 05/30/2025.

evidence.dc:description:
The truncated protein of approximately 2 mD is expressed in
skeletal muscle, but western blot studies with epitope-specific
anti-titin antibodies suggest that the mutant protein is
truncated to a 1.14-mD subfragment by site-specific cleavage.
evidence.rdfs:label: WESTERN BLOTTING

evidence.dc:description:
Immunocytochemical analysis for titin and various proteins marking different
portions of the sarcomere—a-actinin (Z-disk), cardiac troponin T
(cTNT, A-band), and myosin heavy chain (MHC, M-line)—revealed, in the DCM group, a higher percentage of cardiomyocytes in which organized myofibrils occupied only half of the whole cytoplasm or less . Moreover, the immunofluorescence signal of Z-disk titin in striated myofibrils appeared more diffuse in patient cells. These results suggested that truncated titin mutants could alter assembly and/or stability of the sarcomeric units in human
embryonic myocytes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Characterization of Ser14450fsX4 iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes

evidence.dc:description: Human cardiac microtissue (CMTs) expressing either A-band TTNtv or W976R+/− variants exhibited less than half the contractile force or the stress (force normalized to tissue area) generated by pWTs, and function did not improve over time.
evidence.rdfs:label: Study of iPS-CMs with TTN mutations

evidence.dc:description: Experiment does not show that TTNtv is the cause of DCM

Authors observed reduced passive stiffness in TTN mutant cells with no difference in isoform expression (N2BA/N2B or presence of foetal isoforms) and no haploinsufficiency; nor was there incorporation of predicted truncated peptides into the myofibrils in common with other researchers.
evidence.rdfs:label: functional analysis of cardiac myofibrils with TTN mutations

evidence.dc:description:
Mutants treated with mTtnAONs exhibited rescued sarcomere assembly and Z-disk formation and a significant increase in contractile function when compared to untreated or mScrAON-treated homozygous littermates.
Partial skipping of the mutated exon 326 with restoration of Ttn open reading frame is sufficient to prevent the development of the DCM phenotype in vivo.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ttn Ser14450fsX4 knock-in DCM mouse embryos

evidence.dc:description: Excision of TTN exon 326 has a negligible effect on sarcomere structure in both HL-1 cells and human healthy iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes. Skipping of the mutated exon in patient-specific cardiomyocytes carrying the TTN Ser14450fsX4 mutation improved myofibril assembly and stability and normalized the expression of muscle genes regulated by TK.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of TTN Ser14450fsX4 iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes

evidence.dc:description: Mouse model requires ATII to expose the phenotype

When exposed to cardiac stressors (angiotensin II, isoproterenol), heterozygous animals developed typical morphological and functional features of DCM (left ventricular dilatation with impaired systolic function and extended myocardial fibrosis) significantly earlier and more pronounced compared to wild-type mice, thereby recapitulating the human phenotype.

The TTN 2bp-insertion mutation has been reported in a large family with autosomal
dominant DCM causing congestive heart failure with variable phenotypic expression and
age of onset in affected patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Knock-in mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Rat model does not spontaneously develop DCM

Truncating mutations in TTN (TTNtv) impaired cardiac performance during stress in rats. TTNtv rat hearts tended to have higher strain rates and LV developed pressures, perhaps reflecting compensatory metabolism and signalling but, when subjected to sequential volume overload stress, mutant heart function became increasingly impaired.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rat TTNtv models

evidence.dc:description:
The pik heart develops normally but is poorly contractile from the first beat. Aside from the edema that inevitably accompanies cardiac dysfunction, development is normal during the first three days. At the organ level, pik zebrafish exhibited reduction in systolic pressure, because there is little if any blood ejected and the dilated heart empties only little during systole.
The thin-walled, dilated, poorly contractile heart of pik embryos resembles those of people with dilated cardiomyopathy.
Experiments with morpholino antisense oligonucleotides recapitulate the cardiomyopathy phenotype observed in pik zebrafish.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish carrying splice site mutation in TTN

member.rdfs:label: MEW-11

The TTN sequence was assessed in group C by means of traditional Sanger
dideoxy sequencing performed at the Department of Genome Sciences, University of
Washington.

member.detectionMethod:
Blood samples were collected for DNA analysis and studied for rare variants in MYH6 (GenBank accession no. NM_002471 / P13533), MYH7 (GenBank accession no.
NM_000257.2 / NP_000248.2), MYBPC3 (NM_000256.3 /NP_000247.2), TNNT2 (NM_001001430.1 / NP_001001430.1) and TTN (NM_133378 / NM_00319 / NM_133379 / Q8WZ42) by denaturing high performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC) or by Sanger sequencing.

or by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: Haplotype analysis mapped the disease gene in a 9-Mb interval on chromosome 2q31 between microsatellite markers D2S326 and D2S2310, both flanking the TTN locus

member.rdfs:label: III-2
member.detectionMethod: Genetic testing in probands was performed using next generation sequencing (NGS). 44 patients were analyzed by whole exome sequencing (WES), in 22 TruSight One (TSO) sequencing panel and in 6 sequencing of a custom panel of 35 genes involved in cardiomyopathies (ABCC9, ACTC1, ACTN2, ANKRD1, BAG3, CRYAB, CSRP3, DES, EMD, ILK, LAMA4, LDB3, LMNA, MYBPC3, MYH6, MYH7, MYL2, MYL3, MYPN, PDLIM3, PLN, PSEN1, PSEN2, RBM20, SCN5A, SGCD, TAZ, TCAP, TMPO, TNNC1, TNNI3, TNNT2, TPM1, TTN, VCL) were performed.

member.rdfs:label: III-3
member.detectionMethod:
The gene panel (Pan Cardiomyopathy Panel, Blueprint Genetics v.1.0) was designed to screen 2515 consensus coding sequence (CCDS) regions and splice junctions of 51 known
genes and 50 candidate genes associated with DCM and implicated in other inherited cardiomyopathies based on Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man database annotations and literature.

evidence.dc:description: Variant was not scored during original curation
Study design and analyses underwent rigorous statistical review. Findings were confirmed in replication cohorts.

evidence.rdfs:label: TTN truncations in DCM vs controls

caseCohort.detectionMethod:
Targeted re-sequencing: TTN was sequenced in prospective DCM cases, healthy volunteers, and 103 end-stage DCM cases using a targeted approach.
In a subset of end stage patients (n=54) TTN was studied by whole genome sequencing.
In addition to sequencing TTN the authors sequenced known DCM genes used in clinical practice.

controlCohort.detectionMethod: A custom set of hybridization capture probes were designed that targeted cardiovascular disease genes including TTN.

evidence.dc:description: In comparison to controls, TTNtv affecting both the N2BA and N2B isoforms were enriched in the DCM replication cohort (OR=78) 20–460), P = 3.8×10−21), and TTNtv in this cohort were located in more highly expressed exons (P = 7.5×10−4; Table 1, Figs. 1 & 2, Table S13). The predicted probability of pathogenicity of nonsense, frameshift, or canonical splice TTNtv in highly expressed exons in the DCM replication cohort was ≥98% (LR= 41).

caseCohort.detectionMethod: The DCM replication cohort was studied by targeted sequencing approach using an Agilent custom capture that included TTN, followed by sequencing on the Illumina HiSeq 2000 platform.

controlCohort.detectionMethod: WHI exomes were captured and sequenced on the Illumina GenomeAnalyzerII and HiSeq platforms

evidence.dc:description: VUS MISSENSE CHANGE
